Selected Answer: A
The question is formuled in order to take the most correct answer, if you leave the default configuration unmodified it can be aligned or not with the enterprise requirements, if you leave it unverified you can have a lack of due diligence, so it is not an option valid in the case you you want to grant the most optimal sensor upgrade level.
The A option is only explaining the obvious, that you have to align the default policy with the company requirements for all the machines in general just in case some machine will not apply other custom sensor update policies to have a coherent upgrade policy.
So for me A is the correct answer.
A is correct, default policy on all platform is Auto N-1

Selected Answer: C

questions.question_text: Which statement describes what is recommended for the Default Sensor Update policy?

choices.D: No configuration is required. Once a Custom Sensor Update policy is created the Default Sensor Update policy is disabled
choices.A: The Default Sensor Update policy should align to an organization's overall sensor updating practice while leveraging Auto N-1 and Auto N-2 configurations where possible
choices.C: Since the Default Sensor Update policy is pre-configured with recommend settings out of the box, configuration of the Default Sensor Update policy is not required
choices.B: The Default Sensor Update should be configured to always automatically upgrade to the latest sensor version

questions.question_text: You need to have the ability to monitor suspicious VBA macros. Which Sensor Visibility setting should be turned on within the Prevention policy settings?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Correct is Script-based Execution Monitoring, I checked the Falcon Documentation
Turn on the Script-Based Execution Monitoring prevention policy setting to enable the "Falcon sensor to monitor the contents of scripts and shells that are popular mechanisms for executing malicious code on hosts. This setting does not kill or block scripts."
Scripting languages:
Excel 4.0 macros
JScript
VBA Macros
VBScript

Selected Answer: A
A is correct.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
A is correct, Checked through documentation and course slides.

Selected Answer: A
Script-Based Execution Monitoring

For hosts running Windows 10 and Servers 2016 and later, provides visibility into suspicious scripts and VBA macros in Office documents. Requires Quarantine & Security Center Registration toggle to be enabled.

choices.B: It is the dashboard used by an analyst to view all items quarantined and to release any items deemed non-malicious
choices.A: It is designed to give an administrator a quick overview of machine-learning aggressiveness settings as well as the numbers of items actually quarantined
choices.C: It is the dashboard used to see machine-learning preventions, and it is used to identify spikes in activity and possible targeted attacks
choices.D: It is designed to show malware that would have been blocked in your environment based on different Machine-Learning Prevention settings

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct. Check in: "Audit logs > Machine-learning prevention monitoring", and right below the title "Machine-Learning Prevention Monitoring", the description: Use this dashboard to view malware that would have been blocked in your environment over the selected timeframe based on different Machine Learning Prevention settings (Cautious, Moderate, Aggressive or Extra Aggressive)

Selected Answer: D
D is correct, tested in the UI

D is correct. Check through console and documentation.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the Machine-Learning Prevention Monitoring Report?

choices.A: a bar chart where a bar represents a daily count of remote connections
choices.D: a pie chart showing a count per remote logon type
choices.B: a geographical chart showing the geo-location of remote IP address
choices.C: a graph showing connections between hosts and users

discussion.content:
C
Remote Access Graph: Provides a graphical representation of relationships between users and systems that have been remotely accessed. This allows you to search for users who are remotely logged on to devices based on logon type. You can search for either Terminal Server logons (Type 10, for example, RDP) or Network Server (Type 3) logons.
